    Apply Now
  

  
  

    
    
      The Biomedical Research and Data Science Institute (BIODAS) is recruiting a Field Assistant to coordinate with the research team to implement a project on digital transformation in coffee production in Vietnam (Dak Lak, Gia Lai, Lam Dong). The candidate will support field coordination, connect stakeholders, ensure regulatory compliance, and participate in collecting interview data.
    

    
    
      Research project summary
      
        The project examines the impact of digital transformation on sustainable efficiency in coffee production, focusing on smallholder farmers and coffee companies that are applying digital technology both on-farm and off-farm.
        The application of technology ranges from smartphones (accessing information, communication) to sensors (monitoring, optimizing inputs), and is expected to bring economic–social–environmental benefits, improving the coffee industry and value chain.

          Engage the local community.
          Ensure compliance with government regulations/permits.

title: Initiative for strengthening community capacity in data processing and analytics in the digital age
text:
Table of Contents
    
      Background and Rationale
      Objectives
      Research Questions
      Theoretical Basis and Analytical Framework
      Approach
      Expected Outcomes
      References
    
  

  
  
    
    
    
      1. Background and Rationale
      
        In the context of digital transformation, data is increasingly regarded as a strategic resource. The effective use of data plays a central role in policy design and implementation, social governance, and sustainable development. International organizations such as FAO, ESCAP, and the UN have repeatedly emphasized the importance of data capacity in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
      
      
        However, the current situation in many developing countries, including Vietnam, shows a significant lack of skills in data processing and analysis within the community. Many officials, students, and social organizations only have basic access (e.g., basic Excel), while lacking the ability to use more modern tools (Power BI, R, Python, Quarto). This limits the ability to make evidence-based decisions and apply data in local governance.
      

      
        Key international indicators:
        
          
            Mačiulienė & Skaržauskienė (2019): civic tech communities 
            can only develop sustainably when they integrate three pillars: technology, knowledge, and people.
          
          
            FAO (2020): in a project in Papua New Guinea emphasized that the lack of baseline data 
            hindered the development of agricultural policy; continuous training, a standardized data framework, 
            and the application of simple technology (CAPI, GIS) brought about a breakthrough.
          
          
            ESCAP (2025): affirms that digital data governance 
            is a key factor in promoting the SDGs, and requires the active participation of the community.
          
        
      

      
        From these gaps, the implementation of the project "Building a foundation for community data processing and analysis capacity" is both an urgent and long-term requirement in the process of building a digital society in Vietnam.
      
    
    
    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: Internet)
      
    

    
    
      2. Objectives

      2.1 General Objective
      
        
          To develop and validate a community data capacity platform model to enhance the skills, knowledge, and data application capabilities of community groups, thereby contributing to promoting sustainable development and digital transformation.
        
      

      2.2 Specific Objectives
      
        
          Survey and assess the current state of community data capacity in Vietnam.
          
            Design a multi-tiered training program (basic - advanced - applied) based on the following tools: 
            Excel/Power Query/Power Pivot, Power BI, Stata, R/RMarkdown/RShiny, Quarto/Positron, basic Python.
          
          
            Develop an open educational resource system (bilingual Vietnamese - English) with sample datasets that are practical and easy to access.
          
          
            Establish Community Data Labs to create a space for practice, collaboration, and data-driven innovation.
          
          
            Develop and validate a community data literacy maturity model 
            (Community Data Literacy Maturity Model).
          
        
      
    

    
    
      3. Research Questions

      
        
          What is the current state of community data capacity in Vietnam and where are the main gaps?
          Which data analysis tools are most suitable for the needs, level, and resources of the community?
          Can the Community Data Labs model become a sustainable mechanism for enhancing and maintaining community data capacity?
          How can we measure the progress of data capacity at both the individual and community levels?
          Can this model be integrated with international programs (SDGs, FAO, ESCAP) to enhance its impact and scalability?
        
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: Internet)
      
    

    
    
      4. Theoretical Basis and Analytical Framework

      
        Theoretical Basis
        
          
            Civic tech & digital data analytics framework (Mačiulienė & Skaržauskienė, 2019):
            three main networks – Tech/Media, Knowledge, and Human – are the basis for understanding how
            communities interact and develop data capacity.
          
          
            Community capacity (Liberato et al., 2011):
            includes skills development, resource mobilization, network building, leadership, and participatory decision-making;
            can be adapted to measure data capacity.
          
          
            Papua New Guinea experience (FAO, 2020):
            emphasizes the role of baseline data, simple but effective technology, and continuous training
            in enhancing national data capacity.
          
          
            Digital data governance (ESCAP, 2025):
            requires data to be governed transparently, accountably, and sustainably, directly linked to the SDGs.
          
        
      

      
        Research Analytical Framework
        
          Inputs: tools, learning materials, training programs.
          Process: operation within Community Data Labs, where data is collected, processed, analyzed, and shared.
          Outputs: enhanced individual and community data capacity.
        
      
    

    
    
      5. Approach

      
        Mixed-Methods Approach
        
          Combines quantitative surveys (measuring data capacity before and after intervention) and qualitative methods
          (interviews, group discussions) to both quantify the level of change and explain the mechanisms and context of the impact.
        
      

      
        Implementation Activities
        
          Implement the Community Data Labs model in a test-evaluate-adjust cycle,
          ensuring continuous improvement based on experimental feedback from learners and the community.
        
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: Internet)
      
    

    
    
      6. Expected Outcomes

      
        
          
            Enhanced individual capacity: at least 1,000 learners participate in the project and receive training,
            of which 200 achieve an advanced certificate.
          
          
            Strengthened community capacity: a minimum of 10 community projects apply data
            to address priority social issues.
          
          
            Sustainable institution: establishment of an independently operating Community Data Labs.
          
          
            Open educational resource system: publication of bilingual materials (Vietnamese - English), sample datasets, and practical guides,
            that are easy to access and reuse.
          
        
      
    

    
    

  








 Back to topReferences
      References

      
        1) FAO. (2020). Strengthening Capacity for Data Processing, Analysis and Management in Papua New Guinea (TCP/PNG/3604). 
            Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
        .
      
      
        2) Liberato, S. C., Brimblecombe, J., Ritchie, J., Ferguson, M., & Coveney, J. (2011). Measuring capacity building in communities: A review of the literature. BMC Public Health, 11(1), 850.
        https://doi.org/10.1186/1471-2458-11-850.
      
      
        3) Mačiulienė, M., & Skaržauskienė, A. (2019). Building the capacities of civic tech communities through digital data analytics. Journal of Innovation and Knowledge, 5(4), 228–235.
        https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jik.2019.11.005.
      
      
        4) United Nations ESCAP. (2025). Capacity Building Workshop on Digital Data Governance. Bangkok: UN ESCAP

      The BIODAS Team is pleased to share information about the PACE-UP Full PhD Scholarship 2026–2030 – a prestigious scholarship program funded by DAAD, offering research and doctoral training opportunities at leading German universities in the fields of infectious diseases, epidemiology, global health, and antimicrobial resistance.

      Official website: 
        https://paceup.org/opportunities/
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Call for PhD Applications (Source: PACE-UP)
        
      

      1. Program Introduction
      The program is recruiting for fully funded PhD positions in the fields of infectious diseases, epidemiology, global health, and antimicrobial resistance at leading research institutions in Germany, within the framework of the DAAD-funded PACE-UP project.

      PhD students will be based at one of four leading institutions: the University of Tübingen, the University of Lübeck, the University of Hamburg, or in collaboration with the Heidelberg Institute of Global Health.

          Basic laboratory skills and adherence to good laboratory practice standards.

JICA “SDGS GLOBAL LEADER 2026” FULLY FUNDED SCHOLARSHIP
      Opportunity to pursue a Master's/PhD in Japan for officials of the Vietnamese Government

      
      
        APPLY NOW
      
    
  

  
  
    
      
      The BIODAS Team is pleased to share information about the JICA “SDGs Global Leader 2026” Scholarship – a fully funded scholarship program of the Government of Japan through the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) for young and mid-career government officials, as well as potential lecturers/researchers. This is an opportunity to pursue a master's (2 years) or doctoral (3 years) degree at leading Japanese universities completely free of charge, opening up a journey of policy capacity development and a sustainable Vietnam-Japan cooperation network.

      Official website: https://www.jica.go.jp/vietnam/index.html
      Contact JICA Vietnam:
      
        Ms. Nguyen Thi Mai Khanh
        Phone: 84-4-38315005~8 (Ext. 142)
        Email: nguyenthimaikhanh.vt@jica.go.jp
      
      Source: Official Letter No. 722.25/JICA-GI dated September 3, 2025 of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) Office in Vietnam

      
        
          
        
        Illustration (Source: Internet)
      

      1. Introduction to the JICA “SDGs Global Leader” Scholarship
      The “SDGs Global Leader” program is part of the JICA Knowledge Co-Creation Program under the Official Development Assistance (ODA) framework of the Government of Japan. The program aims to develop high-quality human resources capable of contributing to the formulation and implementation of sustainable development policies. Study duration: 2 years (Master's) or 3 years (Doctoral).

      
        
          Policy capacity development: Learn from Japan's unique development experience.
          Expand international network: Connect with future leaders from 111 countries.
          Full scholarship: Covers tuition, living expenses, airfare, and insurance.
          Special JICA-DSP program: Participate in activities, internships at Japanese public/private organizations.
        
      

      2. Who can apply for the JICA Scholarship?
      The scholarship is for young/mid-career government officials, lecturers, or researchers who can contribute to policy and social development in Vietnam.

      ✅ Eligibility requirements:
      
        
          Vietnamese citizen eligible for Japanese ODA.
          Currently working in a government agency, research institute, or university.
          Age: ≤35 (Master's), ≤40 (Doctoral) as of April 1, 2026.
          Degree: Bachelor's (for Master's) or Master's (for Doctoral).
          English: TOEFL iBT ≥80 or IELTS ≥6.5.
          Must be physically present in Japan throughout the course.
        
      

      ❌ Not eligible if:
      
        
          Currently receiving or will receive another scholarship.
          Belong to the military or related organizations.
          Cannot be physically present in Japan.
        
      

      3. Priority research fields
      
        Public Administration/Public Policy
        Finance/Public Financial Management
        International Politics/Diplomacy
        Regional Studies
        Business/International Trade/Investment
        Disaster Risk Reduction
        Maritime Issues
      

      
        
          
        
        Illustration (Image source: Tokyo Institute of Technology - www.titech.ac.jp)
      

      4. JICA Application Guide
      Applicants must be nominated by their home institution and approved by the Government of Vietnam. Applications must be submitted through the Ministry of Finance of Vietnam no later than October 22, 2025.

      Application process:
      
        
          Nomination at the home institution (early September 2025)
          Selection by the higher-level agency (early November 2025)
          Submission of application to JICA through the Ministry of Finance (October 22, 2025)
          Screening by JICA (November 2025)
          Pre-matching with the university (December 2025)
          Official entrance examination (February–June 2026)
          Examination results (June–July 2026)
          Preparation for departure (June–August 2026)
          Enrollment (August–October 2026)
        
      

      Required documents:
      
        
          JICA Application Form (including: personal information, educational background, nominating institution, work experience, statement of commitment)
          Graduation certificate (notarized copy, in English or with an official translation)
          Academic transcript (must contain all grades of all subjects, notarized copy, in English or with a translation)
          English language certificate (TOEFL iBT ≥80 or IELTS ≥6.5)
          Passport or ID card with photo (to verify nationality, name, gender, date of birth)
          2 photos 3x4cm (pasted on the application form)
          Health certificate (examination date must be after April 1, 2026 and submitted to JICA before April 30, 2026)
        
      

      
        
          
        
        Illustration (Source: JICA - www.jica.go.jp)
      

      5. Preparing for the selection process
      JICA evaluates applications based on the research plan and potential for policy contribution. Partner universities will pre-match, after which candidates will participate in the official entrance examination or interview.

      6. Choosing a university and program of study
      Applicants choose a university from JICA's partner list (provided by JICA Vietnam). Each university may have its own requirements.

      7. Improving English skills
      The program is taught in English. The cost of the English test may be reimbursed if taken within the same Japanese fiscal year (April 1 – March 31 of the following year).

      10. Participation conditions

      1. Introduction
      
        The review article 
        
          
            “Considering Biased Data as Informative Artifacts in AI-Assisted Health Care”
          
         
        by Kadija Ferryman (Johns Hopkins University), Maxine Mackintosh (Genomics England), 
        and Marzyeh Ghassemi (MIT), published in The New England Journal of Medicine (2023), 
        presents a new perspective on medical data in the age of artificial intelligence (AI).
      

      
        Instead of viewing biased data as “technical garbage” to be discarded according to the 
        “garbage in – garbage out” principle, the authors argue that these very biases 
        are “informative artifacts” — reflecting 
        the values, practices, and inequalities deeply embedded in the modern healthcare system. 
        Viewing data as “social relics” can help us better understand 
        how technology reflects and sometimes amplifies injustice in healthcare.
      

      
        This perspective suggests that instead of just trying to “fix” the data, 
        the scientific community needs to learn to “read” them — much like archaeologists interpret artifacts 
        to understand ancient societies. Clinical data, when viewed as a type of “artifact,” 
        can reveal much about hospital organization, professional culture, and how society values 
        health and human worth.
      

      
        
          The BIODAS Team presents this overview to encourage critical thinking about 
          how data and algorithms shape health equity. By understanding the origins of bias, 
          we can transform AI from a predictive tool into a tool for detecting health inequalities.
        
      

    

    
      
        
      
      
        Illustrative image (Source: https://www.nejm.org)
      
    


    
    
      2. The Problem
      
        In modern healthcare, AI systems are almost entirely dependent on 
        massive, labeled datasets. When this data reflects differences 
        in race, gender, or socioeconomic status, AI can inadvertently 
        reproduce social biases — a phenomenon known as 
        algorithmic discrimination.
      

      
        
          For example, in a study of chest X-rays, an AI system trained on thousands of images 
          still showed a tendency for underdiagnosis in Black and 
          Hispanic patients, especially women. This happened because 
          the original data did not fairly reflect the disease prevalence in these populations.
        
      

      
        According to Ferryman and colleagues, the problem is not just that the data is “wrong,” but also how we understand it. 
        Clinical data is a product of social context, organizational processes, and professional decisions; 
        therefore, each “bias” is an indicator of the culture and history of the medical field. 
        Instead of eliminating them, we can learn from these biases to improve health equity.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      
        Illustrative image (Source: https://www.quantib.com)
      
    

    
    
      3. Three Key Aspects: When Data Becomes an "Artifact"

      3.1. Data and Social Values
      
        
          “Race correction” in estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) was once considered a scientific improvement, 
          but it actually reflected the assumption that Black people have higher muscle mass – a legacy from a time 
          when the white male body was considered the “biological norm.” 
          When these formulas are incorporated into AI, they continue to reproduce racial stereotypes 
          under the neutral guise of an algorithm.
        
        
          Viewed from an “artifact” perspective, the existence of “race correction” variables is not just a statistical error, 
          but a trace of a historical period when medical science was built on a foundation of racial discrimination. 
          Acknowledging and analyzing the origins of these “hidden values” is the first step 
          towards more responsible medical AI.
        
      

      3.2. Data and Clinical Practice
      
        
          Many electronic health records lack data on gender identity, disability status, or social factors. 
          This “data absence” is not merely a technical error, 
          but reflects a lack of uniformity in medical language, barriers of trust between doctors and patients, 
          and limitations in training healthcare workers on gender diversity. 
          According to the authors, if we approach this from an “artifact” perspective, we can use AI 
          to identify where data is missing, thereby raising questions about equity and representation in healthcare.
        
        
          AI, when used correctly, can detect “data gaps” — 
          such as the lack of data for minority ethnic groups or LGBTQ+ patients — 
          and turn them into signals for deeper research into systemic inequalities.
        
      

      3.3. Data and Health Inequalities
      
        
          In the field of lung cancer, data shows that Black patients are often diagnosed later than white patients, 
          causing AI to “learn” that this group has a worse prognosis. 
          Without considering the social context, the AI model will reinforce the very injustices it should be correcting. 
          By treating data as an artifact, researchers can detect and clarify 
          the systemic chains of exclusion in healthcare, such as lack of access to 
          early screening services, high treatment costs, or biases in the disease classification process.
        
      

      
        “Medical data doesn't just talk about patients – it talks about the entire care system and what society values.”
      
    

    
    
      4. A Sociotechnical Approach
      
        Ferryman and colleagues propose an analytical framework that combines technology, ethics, and society, 
        aiming to broaden the understanding of data bias. Instead of just “patching” technical errors, 
        they suggest a more comprehensive approach that combines data, people, and social context.
      

      
        
          Beyond “data cleaning”: Not just removing biases, but interpreting the socio-historical reasons behind the data.
          Interdisciplinary collaboration: Connecting doctors, engineers, ethicists, and sociologists to co-create solutions.
          Aligning with health equity: Viewing AI not just as a disease detection tool, but as a tool for detecting inequality.
        
      

      
        This approach moves AI beyond the realm of “pure technology,” 
        towards a more reflective and humanistic development model. 
        It also opens up the opportunity to use AI as a sociological tool to illuminate the very unjust structures 
        that the data reflects.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      
        Illustrative image (Source: https://www.wsp.com)
      
    

    
    
      5. Application in Vietnam
      
        In the context of Vietnam building a national health data infrastructure and implementing electronic health records, 
        the “data as artifact” mindset is particularly meaningful:
      

      
        
          It helps assess potential biases in health data, from regional to gender and economic conditions.
          It lays the foundation for a data ethics framework and transparent policies when applying AI in public health.
          It encourages collaboration between medicine, data science, and social sciences to ensure health equity.
        
      
      
      
        National projects such as electronic health records, vaccination data, or disease forecasting systems 
        need to be designed with this socio-technical awareness. 
        Paying attention to data biases (e.g., underrepresentation of patients in remote areas or ethnic minorities) 
        can help prevent the reproduction of inequalities in digital health.
      
      
        Identifying bias is not about discarding data, but about gaining a deeper understanding of the system that produced it — thereby creating sustainable health equity.
      
    

    
    
      6. Conclusion
      
        “Data bias” is not just a technical error – it is a mirror reflecting history, culture, and social structures. 
        By viewing data as “informative artifacts,” we can use AI to illuminate hidden inequalities, 
        instead of inadvertently reinforcing them. 
      
      
        This is the shift from “accurate AI” to “equitable AI” — 
        a necessary direction to ensure that technological progress is always linked to humanism and justice in digital medicine. 
        As Ferryman and colleagues conclude, “a medical AI system is only truly intelligent when it understands the history and human values hidden in the data it learns from.”
      
    

    
    
      7. References
      
        Ferryman K, Mackintosh M, Ghassemi M. Considering Biased Data as Informative Artifacts in AI-Assisted Health Care. N Engl J Med. 2023;389(9):833–838. DOI: 10.1056/NEJMra2214964.

title: AI Revolutionizing Clinical Trials: Optimizing Efficiency and Minimizing Risks
text:

      AI Revolutionizing Clinical Trials

      Automation of Clinical Study Reports

      References
    
  

  

    
    
      
        AI Revolutionizing Clinical Trials: Optimizing Efficiency and Minimizing Risks.
        In the journey of developing new drugs from the laboratory to the market, clinical trials play a crucial but also the most expensive and risky role. 
        With over 80% of clinical trials failing to meet patient recruitment targets, and the cost of developing a new drug potentially reaching billions of dollars over more than a decade, 
        the pharmaceutical industry is seeking breakthrough solutions. Artificial intelligence (AI) is emerging as a powerful transformative force, promising to revolutionize the way clinical trials are designed, 
        conducted, and monitored.[1] The emergence of AI in clinical trials is not merely the application of new technology 
        but represents a fundamental shift in the approach to medical research.
      

      
        
          The BIODAS Team is pleased to present this overview to provide a comprehensive look at 
          patient recruitment & stratification, adaptive trial design, real-time monitoring, and automated reporting using AI;
          while integrating practical examples and applications to optimize efficiency and minimize risks throughout the entire trial lifecycle.
        
      
    

    
    
      1. AI Revolutionizing Clinical Trials
      
        AI is reshaping the entire clinical trial lifecycle – from design, recruitment, data collection to monitoring and reporting. 
        Instead of replacing humans, AI acts as a capacity-enhancing tool, supporting researchers in making faster, more accurate decisions and minimizing manual errors.
      
      
        The application of AI not only helps streamline processes but also brings strategic improvements in drug development. 
        Thanks to its ability to learn from vast amounts of data, AI can predict clinical events, optimize trial duration, detect problems early, and ensure compliance with Good Clinical Practice (GCP) standards.
      
      
        According to a McKinsey report (2025), pharmaceutical companies applying AI in trial design and management can save 15–25% in costs and shorten research time by an average of 8–12 months. 
        This not only helps accelerate the drug launch timeline but also reduces risks for patients participating in the trial.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://emag.medicalexpo.com)
    

    
    
      2. Patient Recruitment and Stratification
      
        Patient recruitment and stratification are among the most difficult and costly stages in clinical research. 
        On average, over 80% of trials fail due to slow or incorrect patient recruitment. 
        AI can help analyze millions of electronic health records (EHRs), genetic data, and population records to quickly identify patients who fit the study criteria.
      

      
        Machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) algorithms help extract unstructured data from medical records, 
        automatically identifying patients at high risk or with characteristics suitable for the trial criteria. 
        This helps speed up recruitment, reduce costs, and limit bias in the study population.[2]
      

      
        
          Digital Twins – "digital replicas" of patients – allow for the simulation of individual responses to specific treatments. 
          This technology is being tested in diseases such as lung cancer, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease to predict treatment efficacy before conducting actual trials. 
          Initial results show that the model's accuracy reaches 85–90% compared to actual results.
        
      

      
        In addition, AI can identify regions and hospitals with the potential for rapid patient recruitment, minimizing study start-up time. 
        A study from Lindus Health shows that applying AI in identifying research sites can increase recruitment speed by 30% and reduce monitoring costs by 20%.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://essentracomponents.bynder.com)
    

    
    
      3. Adaptive Trial Design and Protocol Optimization
      
        Designing a research protocol is a fundamental step that determines the success of a clinical trial. 
        Previously, research teams often spent months building and refining the protocol, 
        while many risks (such as unrealistic criteria or an inappropriate sample size) were only discovered after the study had started. 
        AI helps overcome this through AI-powered Protocol Design – an automated protocol generation tool.[5]
      

      
        Tools like Medidata AI or Quanticate SmartTrial use data from thousands of previous trials to propose optimal study structures, outcome criteria, and sample sizes. 
        As new data is added, the AI model can "learn" and suggest real-time protocol adjustments – the foundation of adaptive trial design.
      
      
        A typical example is in the COVID-19 trial, where the FDA applied a machine learning algorithm to identify a group of patients with high suPAR levels to optimize the treatment efficacy of the drug Anakinra. 
        This is a clear demonstration of how AI can directly improve clinical research outcomes and the licensing decision-making process.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://www.medidata.com)
    

    
    
      4. Real-time Data and Quality Monitoring
      
        Data monitoring is a critical task to ensure integrity, accuracy, and compliance in research. 
        Traditional monitoring systems often detect discrepancies after the data has been entered into the server, 
        causing delays and costs in the error correction process. 
        AI helps shift this process to a "proactive real-time monitoring" model.[6]
      

      
        
          Automated Anomaly Detection: Compares current data with historical data samples to identify discrepancies early.
          CRF Form Optimization: AI suggests reorganizing data entry fields to reduce duplication and errors by research coordinators.
          Data Query Prediction: Deep learning models can predict entry errors before they affect statistical results.
        
      

      
        A typical example is the monitoring system of LookDeep Health, which applies computer vision to monitor patient behavior in real time. 
        This technology allows for the identification of fall risks, procedural deviations, or physiological abnormalities in hospital-based trials.
      
      
        As a result, researchers can intervene early, ensure safety, and minimize research interruptions, 
        while generating more reliable data for post-hoc analyses.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://itdigest.com)
    

    
    
      5. Automation of Clinical Study Reports (CSR)
      
        The Clinical Study Report (CSR) is a mandatory document when submitting data to regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA. 
        Compiling hundreds of tables and statistical analyses often takes weeks of work. 
        However, AI has helped transform this entire process through natural language processing (NLP) and Document AI tools.[Credevo]
      

      
        
          Automated Drafting: NLP extracts data from statistical tables, charts, and analysis software to automatically generate content for the efficacy, safety, and patient distribution sections.
          Consistency Check: AI cross-references the Protocol, Statistical Analysis Plan (SAP), and CSR to detect discrepancies in definitions or figures.
          Automated Formatting: Systems like SmartDocs or eCTD Builder ensure that documents meet FDA/EMA standards without manual adjustments.
        
      

      
        Automating the CSR helps reduce report preparation time by 50–70% and significantly improves document accuracy. 
        Furthermore, research teams can focus on scientific analysis instead of administrative tasks, 
        thereby accelerating the entire "database lock – submission" cycle.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://www.sciencepharma.com)
    

    
    
      6. Challenges and Limitations
      
        Although AI offers many benefits, its implementation in clinical trials still faces major challenges:
      

      
        
          Data Quality: AI algorithms are heavily dependent on training data; incomplete or biased data can lead to biased predictions.
          Regulation and Ethics: Transparency, explainability, and protection of personal information must be ensured.
          Regulatory Acceptance: The FDA and EMA are still in the process of establishing a formal legal framework for "AI-assisted trials."
          Infrastructure Connectivity: Integrating AI into EDC, LIMS, and CTMS systems requires unified data standards (CDISC, HL7 FHIR).
        
      

      
        Despite these barriers, the trend of "AI-driven clinical research" is irreversible. 
        In the next 5 years, AI systems are expected not only to support but also to become a mandatory component in the management and analysis of clinical trials, 
        helping to elevate medical research to be more precise and sustainable.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      Illustrative image (Source: https://nextgeninvent.com)
    

    
    
      7. Conclusion and Future Prospects
      
        Artificial intelligence is fundamentally changing the way clinical trials are designed, implemented, and managed. 
        From patient recruitment, protocol optimization, data monitoring to automated reporting, AI has demonstrated its ability to 
        shorten research time, increase accuracy, reduce costs, and enhance the scientific reliability of the entire process.
      

      
        In the next decade, the combination of AI, Big Data, the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT), and Precision Medicine 
        will usher in a new era – where trials are no longer static, but become flexible, adaptive, and personalized learning systems. 
        Machine learning models can predict disease progression, suggest optimal patient groups, and even automatically adjust research protocols based on real-time data.
      

      
        Three prominent trends by 2030:
        
          
            1. Clinical Trials 4.0 – Automation and Open Data: 
            Clinical trials will gradually become a fully digitized process, integrating data from wearable devices, electronic health records, and remote monitoring systems. 
            AI will play a central role in standardizing, integrating, and analyzing this data for rapid decision-making.
          
          
            2. Virtual & Decentralized Trials (DCT): 
            Decentralized Clinical Trials will become more common thanks to AI-powered remote monitoring, 
            data validation, and maintenance of patient-researcher interaction without face-to-face meetings.
          
          
            3. AI-Governed Trial Intelligence: 
            In the future, AI systems will take on the role of "coordinating intelligence" – monitoring research progress, forecasting risks, 
            optimizing costs, and ensuring compliance with global legal regulations (FDA, EMA, PMDA...).
          
        
      

      
        For Vietnam, the application of AI in clinical trials is still in its early stages, but the potential is enormous. 
        Research centers, hospitals, and universities can start by building standardized data management systems (CDISC, HL7-FHIR) 
        and investing in computational infrastructure – essential foundations for AI-based research. 
        Along with training a multidisciplinary workforce (medicine – data science – biomedical ethics), 
        Vietnam can gradually move towards participating in the global trial network, contributing to the new era of precision medicine.
      

      
        Finally, AI is not just a supportive technology – it is a tool that shapes new scientific thinking. 
        With the combination of human intelligence and the power of machine learning, future clinical trials will not only be "smarter" but also "more humane" – 
        aiming for the ultimate goal: improving the quality of life and ensuring patient safety worldwide.
      
    

    
    
      8. References
      
        [1] Van der Schaar Lab: Adaptive Clinical Trials
        [2] Lindus Health – AI for Clinical Trial Recruitment
        [3] Wang Y, Carter BZ, Li Z, Huang X. Application of Machine Learning Methods in Clinical Trials for Precision Medicine. JAMIA Open. 2022;5(1):ooab107.
        [4] Reprocell Blog – AI in Clinical Trials
        [5] Quanticate – AI in Clinical Trial Design

        The study titled 
        
          
            Acceptance and Adoption of Artificial Intelligence Among Cancer Survivors Seeking Information: A Literature Review
          
                   
        by the author group 
        Prabal Chourasia, Melissa Coffel, Jamie Lynn Conklin, William A. Wood, and Saif Khairat 
        was published in 2025 in the 
        Journal of Patient Experience.
      

      
        The research focuses on exploring the level of acceptance and adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) among cancer survivors when they seek medical information — a topic of increasing importance as AI is changing the face of global healthcare.
      

      
        
          The BIODAS Team is pleased to introduce and share the content of this research with you, 
          to provide a deeper insight into the 
          trust, behavior, and relationship between patients – AI – doctors in the digital medical era. 
          Let's explore the interesting findings from this work in more detail with the BIODAS Team.
        
      
    


    
    
      1. Introduction
      
        Artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare is no longer a foreign concept, but how it is implemented and the level of patient acceptance remain open questions. Although AI has been studied in healthcare since the 1970s, the real boom has only occurred in the last few decades with the potential to improve prognosis, reduce costs, and enhance the quality of care for both doctors and patients. As a multidisciplinary field, AI is gradually becoming a pillar of a patient-centered healthcare system.
      
      
        For cancer patients, specific challenges include the lack of continuous personalized care, and patients often experience anxiety and uncertainty. These anxieties are further exacerbated in linguistic, ethnic, and racial minority groups - vulnerable communities in society. AI applications have shown positive results in mitigating these challenges while aiming to improve quality of life. However, the level of acceptance and adoption of AI by cancer patients is still not well understood.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: xsolis.com)
      
    


    
    
      2. Research Methods
      
        The study “Acceptance and Adoption of Artificial Intelligence Among Cancer Survivors Seeking Information: A Literature Review” by Prabal Chourasia et al. (2025), published in the Journal of Patient Experience, conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines on three main databases: PubMed, Scopus, and CINAHL Plus with Full Text.
      
      
        Inclusion criteria:
        
          Studies surveying people aged 18–99;
          Focusing on cancer patients;
          Assessing the acceptance or adoption of AI in seeking medical information;
          Being original research.
        
      
      
        Exclusion criteria:
        
          Special patient populations (children, pregnant women...);
          Studies focusing on service providers instead of patients;
          Studies not about cancer patients or just conference abstracts.
        
      
      
        The analysis process used a combination of inductive and deductive methods to identify factors of trust in AI, the usability of AI tools, and the role of personalization.
      
    

    
    
      3. Research Results
      
      
      
        
          
        
        
          Acceptance and Adoption of Artificial Intelligence (AI) by Cancer Patients in Information Seeking (Prabal Chourasia, 2025)
        
      

      
        After screening 858 documents and removing duplicates, the research team analyzed 581 articles and selected 12 suitable studies. Among them:
      
      
        5 studies from the United States,
        2 from the UK, 2 from Germany,
        1 from Canada, 1 from Norway, and 1 from China.
      
      
        These studies included patient groups with: skin cancer, meningioma, prostate cancer, breast cancer, gastrointestinal cancer, and metastatic cancer.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: suckhoedoisong.vn)
      
    

    
    
      4. Acceptance of AI in Diagnosis and Decision-Making
      
        
          Patients perceive that AI helps increase diagnostic accuracy, improve access to care, and reduce costs.
          They prefer the “AI-assisted – doctor-decides” model, especially in sensitive situations.
          Nearly half of the respondents were not concerned about AI assisting in the diagnosis of skin cancer.
          Patients trust doctors more than AI in responding to and explaining results.
          AI controlled by a doctor has a significantly higher level of trust than automated AI.
        
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: vneconomy.vn)
      
    

    
    
      5. Adoption of AI in Information Seeking
      
        
          Two prominent applications: AI-based educational chatbots and intelligent online search tools.
          A pre-test genetic counseling chatbot was highly accepted by breast cancer patients.
          Virtual conversational tools were rated as safe, convenient, easy to use, and suitable for home use.
        
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: www.nextcarehealth.com)
      
    

    
    
      6. Ethical Perspectives on AI Use
      
        
          The majority of participants supported being informed when their medical data is used.
          Opposed the sale of medical data for commercial purposes.
          Wanted data to be anonymized and used only in trusted organizations.
        
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: www.bcm.edu)
      
    


    
    
      7. Discussion
      
        The study provides a better understanding of cancer patients' perspectives on the acceptance and adoption of AI. Patient acceptance is a key factor for the successful integration of technology into healthcare.
      
      
        
          Patients see AI as a tool to support doctors, not replace them.
          AI has potential in information education through chatbots and extended search tools.
          AI helps save time for doctors, increasing patient interaction and understanding.
          Ethical aspects and the interpretability of AI models need to be emphasized.
        
      
    

    
    
      8. Application Recommendations for Vietnam
      
        
          Policies and regulations: Develop a clear legal framework, ensuring transparency and patient data protection.
          Training and education: Train medical staff on the use and interpretation of AI results, especially in sensitive information.
          Technology development: Create chatbots and AI tools suitable for Vietnamese culture and language – “AI made in Vietnam”.
          Practical implementation: Apply first at central-level hospitals, then expand.
          Research and evaluation: Survey the attitudes of Vietnamese patients to adjust implementation strategies.
        
      
      
        The success of AI in cancer diagnosis and treatment in Vietnam depends on the balance between technological innovation and maintaining trust between doctors and patients.
      
    

    
    
      9. References
      
        
          Chourasia P, Coffel M, Conklin JL, Wood WA, Khairat S. 
          Acceptance and Adoption of Artificial Intelligence Among Cancer Survivors Seeking Information: A Literature Review. 
          J Patient Exp. 2025 Sep 26;12:23743735251380949. 
          doi: 10.1177/23743735251380949.

text:

      Introduction
      A New Approach in Medicine
      Central Role in Basic Research
      Transforming the Clinical Model
      Revolutionizing Diagnosis through Artificial Intelligence
      Challenges and Limitations
      Conclusion
      References
    
  

  
  

    
    
      1. The Importance of Biomedical Data Science: The Driving Force of Modern Medical Transformation
      Introduction
      
        In the era of the digital revolution, medicine is undergoing a powerful transformation — from relying on clinical experience and personal intuition to a model based on data evidence.
      
      
        The explosion of data in the medical and biological fields, from genomics, proteomics to electronic health records (EHR), poses a challenge: how to transform this huge amount of data into valuable knowledge for patient care.
      
      
        The answer lies in Biomedical Data Science — an interdisciplinary field that harnesses big data to drive innovation and biomedical discovery. [1]
      
    

    
      
      
    

    
    
      2. A New Approach in Medicine
      
        Biomedical data science is not just about applying technology to medicine, but a completely new approach to understanding and solving complex problems in healthcare.
      
      
        As researchers at Wake Forest School of Medicine have noted, we are living in an era of huge and diverse data — but the challenge is not just in collecting, but also in assessing the quality and reliability of the data.
      
      
        This requires the development of skills and thinking in biomedical data analysis to be able to work effectively in the era of big data.
      
    

    
    
      3. Central Role in Basic Research [3]
      
        The importance of biomedical data science is clearly demonstrated by the legacy of the Human Genome Project (HGP), a revolutionary milestone that transformed modern biology through the model of “integrated big science”.
      

      
        
          
        
        
          Illustration (Source: HGP-NIH)
        
      

      
        The impact of the HGP is profound and multidimensional. The sequencing of the genomes of microorganisms, plants, and animals has revolutionized many scientific fields, from microbiology, virology, infectious diseases to genetics.
      
      
        Thanks to the ability to sequence the DNA of cancer cells and compare it with data from the HGP, scientists can identify mutated genes, thereby improving the understanding of genetic diseases and developing targeted therapies.
      
    

    
    
      4. Transforming the Clinical Model Through Learning Health Systems [4][6]
      
        In the clinical field, biomedical data science is promoting a new model called Learning Health Systems (LHS).
      
      
        Collecting data from routine clinical practice;
        Analyzing data to extract new knowledge;
        Translating that knowledge back into practice to improve patient care.
      
      
        This model represents a shift from “slow evidence” to “living evidence,” helping the healthcare system to learn and adapt continuously based on real-world data.
      
    

    
      
        
      
      
        Image: The learning cycle from data, knowledge to practice (Source: www.cambridge.org)
      
    

    
    
      5. Revolutionizing Diagnosis Through Artificial Intelligence [5]
      
        One of the most prominent applications of biomedical data science is medical imaging diagnosis using AI.
        A recent meta-analysis of 83 studies showed that some generative AI models have diagnostic performance comparable to non-specialist physicians — with a difference of only 0.6% in accuracy.
      
      
        This opens up great prospects in supporting diagnosis in areas with a shortage of medical personnel, while emphasizing the potential of AI in expanding access to healthcare.
      

      
        
          
        
      
        Illustration (Source: Internet)
      
      
    

    
    
      6. Challenges and Limitations
      
        Data quality: Inaccurate, incomplete, or outdated data can lead to analytical biases and risks for patients.
        Ethics and privacy: The collection, sharing, and use of medical data must strictly adhere to the principles of information governance, fairness, transparency, and accountability.
        Human resources capacity: Requires a team with interdisciplinary knowledge of medicine, statistics, informatics, and data ethics.
      
    

    
    
      7. Conclusion
      
        Biomedical data science has become a pillar of modern medicine.
        From decoding the human genome to developing learning health systems, this field creates a synergy that helps solve many complex medical problems.
      
      
        Although there are still many challenges, the potential to improve treatment outcomes and reduce healthcare costs is undeniable.
        Continuous investment in research, data infrastructure, and international cooperation will be key to maximizing the potential of biomedical data science in the future.
      
    

    
    
      8. References
      [1] Wikipedia: Biomedical Data Science
      [2] YouTube: AI in Brain MRI

    1. Summary
    
      The rapid development of digitization is reshaping medical research, from the creation, storage, and analysis of data to its application in clinical practice. At the heart of this trend is the combination of artificial intelligence (AI) and modern biobanks, opening up opportunities for scientific research and improving the quality of healthcare.
    

    
      Today's biobanks not only store physical samples but also integrate diverse data systems: clinical, genomic, imaging, and lifestyle. When standardized and linked, this data becomes the foundation for advanced AI analysis, which can identify predictive markers, model disease progression, and support personalized medicine.
    

    
      Besides the great potential, the application of AI and the digitization of biobanks pose urgent requirements for governance, ethics, law, and society, to ensure privacy, fairness, and trust in research. This presentation will provide an overview of practical experience from the IARC/WHO biobank, current projects, and future directions.

title: Emerging Frontiers in Biomedical Research: Data Science as the Architect of Future Healthcare
text:
Table of Contents
    
      General Introduction
      Multimodal Data Integration
      Real-World Evidence
      Digital Biomarkers
      Clinical Decision Support Systems
      Challenges and Development Opportunities
      Conclusion
      References
    
  

  
  

    
    
      1. General Introduction
      New Directions in Biomedical Research: Data Science Shapes the Future of Healthcare
      
        Biomedical data science is becoming the foundation of modern medical breakthroughs — 
        not through overly complex technologies, but by effectively harnessing the data already available in the healthcare system. 
        New research directions focus on integrating multi-source data, 
        building evidence from clinical practice, 
        developing digital biomarkers, 
        and applying predictive analytics to improve treatment outcomes. 
        These advances are creating significant changes in healthcare.
      
    

    
    
      2. Multimodal Data Integration: A Comprehensive Picture of Health
      
        Hao Y, Cheng C, Li J, Li H, Di X, Zeng X, Jin S, Han X, Liu C, Wang Q, Luo B, Zeng X, Li K. 
        Multimodal Integration in Health Care: Development With Applications in Disease Management. 
        J Med Internet Res. 2025 Aug 21;27:e76557. doi: 10.2196/76557. PMID: 40840463; PMCID: PMC12370271.
      

      
        Multimodal data integration is revolutionizing how we understand patient health, 
        by combining different data sources such as medical imaging, electronic health records, genomic data, 
        and information from wearable devices. This approach provides a multidimensional view of the patient's condition, 
        enhancing the ability to diagnose, treat, and manage diseases.
      

      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Multimodal models integrate features from multiple data types. Sub-models first extract unimodal features from each data type. Next, the multimodal integration step creates cross-modal features — illustrated here by a Tensor Fusion Network (TFN). A final sub-model infers the patient's outcome. GPU: graphics processing unit. (Source: Boehm KM, Khosravi P, Vanguri R, Gao J, Shah SP. Harnessing multimodal data integration to advance precision oncology. Nat Rev Cancer. 2022 Feb;22(2):114-126. doi: 10.1038/s41568-021-00408-3. Epub 2021 Oct 18. PMID: 34663944; PMCID: PMC8810682.)
        
      

      
        In oncology, multimodal data allows for more accurate tumor characterization 
        and supports the development of personalized treatment plans. 
        One study showed that combining these data types can accurately predict treatment response with 
        Anti–Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 (Anti-HER2) with an AUC = 0.91. 
        In ophthalmology, integrating genetic and imaging data helps in the early detection of retinal diseases.
      

      
        However, multimodal data integration still faces many challenges, 
        such as inconsistency in collection, incomplete or erroneous data that reduces the reliability of the model. 
        To be effective, data standardization, rigorous preprocessing, and interdisciplinary validation are needed 
        to ensure the quality of predictive analysis.
      
    

    
    
      3. Real-World Evidence: From Clinical Trials to Practice
      
        Manfred Stapff. The Importance of Real-World Evidence in Medical Research and Drug Development. 
        Applied Clinical Trials. 2025.
        Dang A. Real-World Evidence: A Primer. Pharmaceut Med. 2023 Jan;37(1):25-36. 
        doi: 10.1007/s40290-022-00456-6. PMID: 36604368; PMCID: PMC9815890.
      

      
        Real-World Evidence (RWE) represents a shift in medical research: 
        from relying solely on randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to harnessing data from everyday healthcare practice. 
        RWE is scientific evidence on the safety and effectiveness of a medical product, 
        generated from Real-World Data (RWD) – data collected during routine care.
      

      
        Sources of RWD include electronic health records (EHRs), registries, insurance data, 
        and data from personal health applications or devices. 
        A study comparing the effectiveness of multiple myeloma treatment between clinical trials and real-world data showed that: 
        patients in RWD were often older, and the results indicated that 6 out of 7 real-world treatment regimens 
        had a 1.44 times lower progression-free survival and a 1.75 times lower overall survival compared to the corresponding RCTs.
      

      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Real-world data (RWD) sources – Created by EUPATI (Source: European Patients’ Academy on Therapeutic Innovation)
        
      

      
        RWE has the potential to fill research gaps, especially for rare diseases, 
        where many patients cannot participate in traditional trials. 
        In addition, RWE supports health policy planning, resource allocation, 
        and evaluation of treatment effectiveness in a real-world setting, 
        contributing to reducing health inequalities.
      
    

    
    
      4. Digital Biomarkers: Continuous Health Monitoring
      
        Babrak LM, Menetski J, Rebhan M, Nisato G, Zinggeler M, Brasier N, Baerenfaller K, Brenzikofer T, 
        Baltzer L, Vogler C, Gschwind L, Schneider C, Streiff F, Groenen PMA, Miho E. 
        Traditional and Digital Biomarkers: Two Worlds Apart? Digit Biomark. 
        2019 Aug 16;3(2):92-102. doi: 10.1159/000502000. PMID: 32095769; PMCID: PMC7015353.
      

      
        In modern medicine, biomarkers are indispensable tools for assessing health status. 
        The development of digital devices and mobile applications has created a new generation – digital biomarkers, 
        providing continuous, objective, and personalized data like never before.
      

      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Digital technologies have enabled the measurement of digital biomarkers. Traditional biomarkers are divided into seven groups depending on the clinical goal (e.g., safety, predictive, diagnostic, etc.). The study suggests that digital technologies open up the possibility of measuring digital biomarkers, which offer new and unique properties (such as continuous measurement over time) while still addressing the same clinical goals as traditional biomarkers. Traditional and Digital Biomarkers: Two Worlds Apart? Digit Biomark. 2019 Aug 16;3(2):92-102. doi: 10.1159/000502000. PMID: 32095769; PMCID: PMC7015353.)
        
      

      
        Traditional biomarkers include indicators such as cholesterol, blood pressure, BMI... 
        Meanwhile, digital biomarkers are defined as “objective, quantifiable physiological and behavioral measures 
        collected and measured by means of digital devices that are portable, wearable, implantable, or digestible.” 
        The key difference is the ability for continuous monitoring, which helps in the early detection of health changes.
      

      
        Digital biomarkers have shown potential in many areas:
        detecting the risk of dementia through computerized cognitive tests,
        monitoring movement in Huntington's disease,
        and assessing Parkinson's symptoms through a finger-tapping test on a smartphone.
      

      
        Despite their great potential, this field still faces challenges in standardizing definitions, 
        data security, and a slow approval process – which need to be improved to expand clinical applications.
      
    

    
    
      5. AI-Driven Clinical Decision Support Systems
      
        Elhaddad M, Hamam S. AI-Driven Clinical Decision Support Systems: An Ongoing Pursuit of Potential. 
        Cureus. 2024 Apr 6;16(4):e57728. doi: 10.7759/cureus.57728. PMID: 38711724; PMCID: PMC11073764.
      

      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) Market (Source: Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) Market Globally by 2022: Worldwide Top Key Players - Agfa Healthcare, McKesson, Carestream Health, AthenaHealth, Philips Healthcare, Wolters Kluwer NU, Cerner. www.openpr.com)
        
      

      
        AI-driven Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) are revolutionizing the medical decision-making process, 
        thanks to their ability to analyze complex data and identify hidden patterns.  
        In diagnostic imaging, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have achieved performance comparable to experts 
        in skin cancer classification (Esteva et al.).  
        In cardiovascular risk prediction, deep learning models using EHRs help identify high-risk patients early, 
        allowing for early intervention and prevention of complications.
      
    

    
    
      6. Challenges and Development Opportunities
      
        Besides progress, the field of biomedical data science faces major challenges:  
        data security and privacy; system compatibility between hospitals, 
        especially with older infrastructure; and the slow pace of technology adoption in some healthcare facilities.
      

      
        However, the development opportunities in Vietnam are enormous. 
        With a population of over 100 million, Vietnam possesses a valuable source of medical data for training AI models. 
        The government is promoting digital transformation in healthcare, 
        with a National Data Development Fund worth 1,000 billion VND (2025) — 
        a significant step to promote innovation and AI application in medicine.
      
    

    
    
      7. Conclusion
      
        New research directions in biomedical data science demonstrate a practical, effective, and patient-oriented approach.  
        From integrating multi-source data to real-world evidence, from digital biomarkers to intelligent decision support systems —  
        all are aimed at the common goal: improving treatment quality, reducing costs, and promoting personalized medicine in the data era.

      Digital Transformation of Vietnam's Healthcare – The Journey to Modernize the Healthcare System
      
        Vietnam is undergoing a comprehensive digital transformation in its healthcare sector, with the ambition of building a modern, intelligent, and efficient healthcare system. 
        From digitizing medical records to applying artificial intelligence (AI) in diagnosis, Vietnam is gradually asserting its new position in the region in medical technology, demonstrated through groundbreaking policies, extensive international cooperation, and strong investment in research – development (R&D).
      
      
        Digital transformation is no longer just a trend but a necessity to enhance the capacity of the healthcare system, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic – when data, connectivity, and technology proved their vital role in protecting public health. 
        Vietnam aims to transform its healthcare mindset and model, putting people at the center, data as the foundation, and technology as the driving force for development.
      

      
        The BIODAS Team synthesizes from official sources of the Ministry of Health and WHO, updating policies, results, and challenges in Vietnam's healthcare digital transformation journey to 2030.
      

    

    
    
      1. Introduction
      
        Vietnam is entering a period of strong digital transformation in all fields, with healthcare being a pioneering sector. 
        The goal is to build a people-centered healthcare system that integrates digital technology, big data, and artificial intelligence to optimize management, treatment, and disease prevention.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: https://svitla.com)
      
    


    
    
      2. Digital Health Transformation Policy Framework
      
        The Vietnamese government has shown strong determination in modernizing the healthcare system through strategic policies. 
        Resolution No. 57-NQ/TW of the Politburo (2023) sets out a vision to 2030: 
      
      
        To be among the top 50 countries in the world in terms of digital competitiveness;
        To be among the top 3 leading countries in Southeast Asia in research and development of artificial intelligence.
      
      
        The Digital Health Transformation Project for the period 2023–2025 concretizes this vision with 5 pillars: 
        data infrastructure development, digital health ecosystem, application of AI and Big Data, information security, and training of digital health human resources.
      

      
        Update from the Ministry of Health (2024)
        At the Health Partnership Group Meeting, Minister Dao Hong Lan emphasized that digital transformation is a strategic priority to achieve Universal Health Coverage (UHC) and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
        
          Issued Resolution 157-NQ/BCSD and Decision 5316/QD-BYT with a vision to 2030.
          Implemented electronic health records integrated with VNeID, electronic medical records, Telehealth, cashless payments, a national pharmaceutical database, and AI applications in diagnosis.
        
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Minister of Health Dao Hong Lan, Deputy Minister of Health Nguyen Tri Thuc, WHO Representative in Vietnam, Dr. Angela Pratt co-chaired the meeting (Source: https://moh.gov.vn)
        
      

      
        Update from the Ministry of Health (2022)
        Deputy Minister Prof. Dr. Tran Van Thuan affirmed that digital transformation played a major role in controlling the COVID-19 pandemic, through platforms for medical declaration, testing, vaccination, remote medical examination, and online consultation.
        
          More than 1,000 facilities have implemented Telehealth nationwide.
          Project 06 on electronic identification is the foundation for connecting national health data.
          Currently finalizing the Decree on health data management and updating Circulars 46/2018, 49/2017, 54/2017.
        
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          Image: Vinh City General Hospital has implemented medical examination and treatment registration using chip-based citizen identification cards or through the VNEID application - electronic identification account (Source: https://moh.gov.vn)
        
      
    

    
    
      3. Electronic Health Book – A Historic Breakthrough
      
        One of the historic milestones is the Electronic Health Book, implemented from July 1, 2025, according to Decree 102/2025/ND-CP. 
        This is a platform connecting people, doctors, medical facilities, and insurance – helping each citizen have a unified electronic health record.
      
      
        The Electronic Health Book is not only a storage tool but also an intelligent health data ecosystem, where doctors can quickly access information, people can monitor their own health, 
        and state agencies can analyze data to plan effective policies.
      
      
        Update: Directly integrated with VNeID, allowing for medical examinations using citizen ID cards, cashless payments, reducing administrative procedures, and increasing transparency in health insurance payments.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Illustration (Source: https://bvhungvuong.vn/)
      
    

    
    
      4. Building a Unified Health Data Management System
      
        Vietnam is building a centralized, unified, and intelligent health data management system, connecting seamlessly from the central to the grassroots level. 
        The system allows for the storage, retrieval, and analysis of all medical examination and treatment data, drug use, and insurance, serving proactive forecasting and disease prevention.
      
      
        Local practice: In Nghe An, 100% of medical facilities have applied software for electronic health insurance management and payment, achieving 97% of the population with health records, and many hospitals have implemented electronic medical records and linked data with the central system.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Image: A medical staff member uses a QR code scanner on a chip-based citizen ID card to look up patient information at the Tan Yen District Health Center, Bac Giang (Source: Dong Thuy/VNA)
      
    

    
    
      5. Development of Vietnamese Human Genetic Medicine
      
        The VinBigData project has completed the first reference genome for the Vietnamese people, creating an important scientific foundation for precision medicine.
        Genetic data helps predict the risk of chronic diseases (cardiovascular, diabetes, cancer) and adverse drug reactions, opening a new era of personalized treatment in Vietnam.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Image: After collection, biological samples are processed at the ISO 15189-standard laboratory at Vinmec International General Hospital (Source: https://nhandan.vn/)
      
    

    
    
      6. Challenges and Solutions
      
        Personal data leakage and the risk of illegal exploitation.
        Data fragmentation, lack of security encryption.
        Cyberattacks (ransomware) on hospital systems.
        Inconsistent legal framework between levels.
        Digital divide between urban and rural areas.
      
      
        WHO recommends: Vietnam needs to invest heavily in health cybersecurity, train data governance personnel, and ensure digital equity – leaving no one behind.
      
    

    
    
      7. The Future of Digital Health in Vietnam
      
        The future of healthcare in Vietnam is an intelligent, connected, people-centered system, where technology is the tool, data is the resource, and trust is the foundation.
        With the companionship of WHO, WB, UNDP, and technology companies, Vietnam is building a sustainable digital health ecosystem, connecting the digital government – digital economy – digital society.
      
      
        By 2030, Vietnam aims to become a leading country in Southeast Asia in digital health, where people are proactively cared for and protected by data, technology, and innovation.

title: Building Smarter Medical AI from a Century of Patient Cases: Dr. CaBot and CPC-Bench
text:
Table of Contents
    
      Highlights

      Research Methods
      Key Results
      Discussion
      Conclusion
      References
    
  

  
  

    
    
      
        The BIODAS Team is pleased to share with you a recently published work from 
        Harvard Medical School — a major milestone in the history of medical artificial intelligence: 
        “Advancing Medical Artificial Intelligence Using a Century of Cases” (Buckley TA, Conci R, Brodeur PG, et al., 2025).
      
      
        For the first time in the nearly 200-year history of the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM), 
        an AI-generated diagnosis has been published alongside that of a human physician. 
        This AI system is named Dr. CaBot – a “virtual doctor” trained on more than 
        7,102 real patient cases published by NEJM over a century (1923–2025).
      

      
        
          The work was led by Thomas Buckley and Arjun K. Manrai, 
          of the Manrai Lab, Department of Biomedical Informatics, Harvard Medical School, 
          in collaboration with Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and Massachusetts General Hospital.  
          The study also introduces CPC-Bench – the world's first benchmark for evaluating the 
          reasoning, diagnostic, and explanatory capabilities of medical AI models.
        
      
    

    
    
      1. Study Highlights
      
        
          NEJM publishes an AI-generated diagnosis for the first time – Dr. CaBot presents alongside a real doctor.
          Dr. CaBot can analyze, reason, and present clinically in the style of CPCs.
          CPC-Bench includes 7,102 CPC cases and 1,021 NEJM Image Challenges, validated by physicians.
          OpenAI o3 achieves top-1 diagnostic accuracy = 60%, top-10 = 84%, 
              surpassing 20 internists (24% and 45%).
          In a blind test, 74% of physicians mistook Dr. CaBot for a human – AI was rated higher for the quality of its reasoning.
          The entire project is publicly available at: https://cpcbench.com
        
      
    

    
    
      2. About the study
      
        Title: Advancing Medical Artificial Intelligence Using a Century of Cases
        Authors: Thomas A. Buckley, Riccardo Conci, Peter G. Brodeur, Jason Gusdorf, Sourik Beltrán, 
        Bita Behrouzi, Byron Crowe, Jacob Dockterman, Muzzammil Muhammad, Sarah Ohnigian, Andrew Sanchez, 
        James Diao, Aashna P. Shah, Daniel Restrepo, Eric S. Rosenberg, Andrew S. Lea, Marinka Zitnik, 
        Scott H. Podolsky, Zahir Kanjee, Raja-Elie E. Abdulnour, Jacob Koshy, Adam Rodman & Arjun K. Manrai.
      
      
        Institution:
        Department of Biomedical Informatics, Harvard Medical School · Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center · 
        Massachusetts General Hospital · Kempner Institute for the Study of Natural and Artificial Intelligence, Harvard University.
      
      Contact: Arjun_Manrai@hms.harvard.edu
          Source: arXiv:2509.12194
      
    

    
    
      3. Introduction
      
        Artificial intelligence (AI) is changing the approach to diagnosis and clinical decision-making. 
        However, most models are evaluated based on output accuracy, 
        while clinical reasoning – the process of analysis and inference leading to a diagnosis – 
        is the core value of medicine.
      
      
        Clinicopathological Conferences (CPCs), 
        initiated by Dr. Richard Cabot in 1923 at Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH), 
        are where experts present, argue, and defend diagnoses based on real patient case data.  
        After a century, NEJM has published over 7,000 CPC cases – an invaluable data repository describing how humans think in medicine.  
        The Harvard team realized that this was the foundation for building a generation of AI that could reason like a real doctor.
      
    

    
    
      
        
      
      
        Image: Overview of CPC-Bench and Dr. CaBot (Source: arXiv (2025). DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2509.12194)
      
    

    
    
      4. Research Methods
      
        Collected 7,102 CPC cases (1923–2025) and 1,021 NEJM Image Challenges (2006–2025).
        Built CPC-Bench – a benchmark consisting of 10 medical tasks (diagnosis, testing, literature search, imaging...).
        Data was annotated and validated by 10 internists (5 residents, 5 attending physicians).
        Developed the Dr. CaBot system based on the OpenAI o3 model, 
            capable of finding similar cases, simulating the writing style of CPC experts, 
            and generating conference videos using LaTeX Beamer + TTS-HD.
        Compared with 20 internists and conducted a “blind” test to evaluate the human-likeness of the AI.
      
    

    
    
      5. Key Results
      
        
          OpenAI o3 achieved Top-1 = 60%, Top-10 = 84%, 
          far surpassing the physician group (24% and 45%). The accuracy of selecting appropriate tests reached 98%.  
          In the “blind” test, 74% of physicians mistook the AI for a human – 
          and even rated Dr. CaBot higher for reasoning and educational appeal.
        
      

      
        
          In imaging, Gemini 2.5 Pro achieved 84%, o3 achieved 82%, and GPT-4o achieved 75%.  
          However, AI is still weak in X-rays and histopathology (55–67%).  
          When analyzing the history of CPCs over 100 years, the team discovered a shift in pathology: 
          from 56% infectious diseases (1920s) to 68% cancer (1950s), 
          and Dr. CaBot achieved comparable – even slightly better – performance than human experts in the 2000–2010 period.
        
      

    

    
    
      6. Discussion
      
        
          The results show that large language models (LLMs) not only reproduce information but also reproduce medical thinking.  
          CPC-Bench has become a standardized measure, helping the scientific community track the progress of AI in clinical diagnosis.  
        
      
      
      
        
          Dr. CaBot promises to become a powerful teaching tool in medical education, 
          where learners can discuss directly with AI, learn how to form hypotheses, and perform multi-level reasoning.  
          However, the Harvard team notes that AI still needs to improve its ability to search literature, process images, 
          and adhere to ethical standards and patient data privacy.
        
      
    

    
    
      7. Conclusion
      
        From Dr. Richard Cabot of the 20th century to Dr. CaBot of the 21st century, 
        the century-long journey of CPCs has come full circle between humans and artificial intelligence.  
        Dr. CaBot demonstrates that AI not only provides answers, 
        but also understands and explains clinical thinking – the foundation of the medical profession.  
      
      
        
          “Dr. CaBot does not replace doctors, but demonstrates the collaboration between humans and machines in the journey of understanding medicine.”  
          — Harvard Medical School research team
        
      
    

    
    
      References

        Brinkmann R. et al. (2024). Building a Community of Medical Learning – A Century of Case Records of the MGH in the Journal. N Engl J Med, 391(9):858–863.
